Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Dean Wilcox from Dartmouth College to quantitatively characterize the thermodynamics of metal ion binding to proteins. This research will provide insight in a) the contributions of metal ions to the stability of proteins, and b) the modulation by the proteins of the redox properties of bound metal ions. Using primarily microcalorimetry methods and systematic perturbations of the protein (site specific mutations) and of the metal (e.g., isostructural Zn2+, Co2+, Cd2+), the enthalpic and entropic components of the metal binding will be quantified, as will be the metal and the protein contributions to the stability of the metalloprotein. Additionally, the contribution of solvation to metal-protein interactions will be evaluated by determining solvent effects on the thermodynamics of metal binding to the protein. In a novel application of these methods, the thermodynamics of metal binding to a protein will be determined when the metal ions is in two oxidation states, and the enthalpic and entropic components of the metal reduction potential, which is modulated by the protein, will be quantified.

Essential trace metals are normally bound to proteins in living organisms. The metals play crucial roles, including a structural role, where the metal (often zinc) helps to stabilize the active form of a protein, and a catalytic role in essential reaction, where the protein tunes the chemical properties of a metal (such as copper). Both the stabilization of a protein by a metal and the influence by a protein of the properties of metal ion will be quantified with experimental methods and analysis pioneered by Wilcox and his students. The proposed research will seek insight in the prevalence, placement and importance of so-called structural metals in proteins; this insight may guide the engineering of metal ions into therapeutic proteins for enhanced stability. Conversely, the identification of the features of a protein that influence the properties of a bound metal will help us to understand how Nature controls and uses the unique reactions of metals. Students working on this project gain extensive knowledge at the interface between inorganic, physical and biochemistry and learn skills important for careers in science and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several metals (e.g., zinc, copper) play essential biochemical roles, while others (e.g., mercury, lead) are toxic. For both types of metals, their import, transport and use, or misuse, in living organisms involves them binding to proteins. This research has pioneered the use of isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) to quantify the fundamental thermodynamics (enthalpy, entropy) that determine how tightly metal ions bind to proteins, and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) to quantify the fundamental thermodynamics (enthalpy, entropy) of the additional stability that is provided to proteins by bound metal ions. In addition, a protocol has been developed to use ITC measurements to quantify the fundamental thermodynamics (enthalpy, entropy) of protein modulation of the oxidation/reduction properties of bound metal ions.

As a model for the fundamental insight that can be provided about metal-protein interactions from ITC and DSC measurements, we have studied the protein insulin (Ins) that is used to regulate blood sugar levels and is synthesized in the liver, where it is stored in vesicles as a zinc-stabilized hexamer (Zn2Ins6) that is resistant to degradation. Measurements with ITC have shown that the insulin hexamer is very stable due to both enthalpic and entropic contributions. We have also quantified the additional stability of the hexamer that is provided by chloride and calcium ions in the vesicles and by phenols that are used in pharmaceutical insulin formulations. Further, we have discovered that the stability of the hexamer depends on pH, which leads to lower stability when it is released into the blood stream, thereby allowing it to dissociate into individual insulin proteins (see figure) that can bind to their receptors. The “chelation” ITC measurements that were used and the data analysis that we pioneered to quantify zinc stabilization of the insulin hexamer have proven to be essential for investigating metal ions binding to other proteins. This has included, in collaboration with colleagues in Australia, zinc, cobalt and manganese binding to the enzymes OpdA and GpdQ that require two metal ions for the hydrolysis of metabolites and the degradation of nerve agents. It has also included, in collaboration with NSF-supported colleague Rachel Austin of Bates College, determining the competition between toxic lead and essential zinc for binding to the protein metallothionein that is found in neural tissue of the brain. Finally, DSC measurements of the enzyme carbonic anhydrase with its essential zinc and with other metal ions have revealed a fundamental thermodynamic advantage of the native zinc.

            Another application of ITC that this research has pioneered for fundamental insight involves metalloproteins that play essential roles in oxidation/reduction (redox) processes. The metal that is bound to these proteins donates and accepts an electron, and the copper-containing protein azurin has been studied as a model redox metalloprotein. By quantifying the thermodynamics of both the electron accepting (Cu(II)) and the electron donating (Cu(I)) metal ion binding to the protein, we have demonstrated that it is possible to determine the thermodynamics of the overall reduction of the metalloprotein. This method can now be used to investigate the thermodynamic basis for protein modulation of the redox properties of a bound metal ion.
